awd_titl_txt: Optimal Order Execution Using Equilibrium Theory and Big Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The investigator, his collaborators, and his students seek to develop mathematical models for how to optimally buy or sell a given quantity of stocks over a short time interval. The project's novelty lies in the fact that both mathematics and equilibrium theory from the economics literature will be used to develop models which: (i) endogenize stock price dynamics as model output, and (ii) can deal with Big Data issues such as the very frequent arrival of massive amounts of new relevant data points. Currently, all trade execution models used by both practitioners and academics are not based on the sound and long standing economic principle which says that the stock price should be determined by equating stock demand with available stock supply. The goal is to build mathematically tractable models based on equilibrium theory which can deal with several Big Data issues.

From a rigorous mathematical perspective, the investigator first seeks to prove existence of equilibria in continuous-time execution models governed by Brownian motions and more generally governed by Levy processes. Subsequently, the investigator seeks to investigate uniqueness and stability of these models. It is suspected that uniqueness fails which implies a refinement need: How to optimally choose an equilibrium? This optimization produces a new class of problems in mathematical finance related to the theory of calculus of variations from analysis. Furthermore, the equilibrium models are carefully designed such that while being mathematically tractable, the models can deal with many of the practical issues Big Data represent. The main Big Data issue to be addressed is the continuous arrival of new relevant data which forces the model implementation to be as an online algorithm.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Rutgers, the State University of New Jersey

por.por_cntn:
The research conducted based on NSF funds is in the area of mathematical finance and is primarily aimed at creating equilibrium models in which traders are asymmetric. This asymmetry produces many new mathematical challenges. The project's main new innovation is a new model in which one group of  traders have individual private trading targets whereas traders in the other group all track an exogenous trajectory (Brownian motion). Together with X. Chen, J. Choi, and D. Seppi, we proved existence of a subgame perfect Nash equilibrium. The award has also helped produce new results related to uniqueness of PDEs (joint with U. Cetin) for strict local martingale models, and a new Kyle model in which the insider faces a personal trading target (joint with J. Choi and H. Kwon). The research projects have been interdisciplinary in the sense that several papers have involved Ph.D. students (X. Chen and H. Kwon) as well as researchers from outside the math community (Duane Seppi).

The broader impacts related to the grant include mentoring of Ph.D. students (both theses by H. Kwon and X. Chen are related to problems proposed in the original NSF proposal). The PI has also used part of the proposal to work with undergraduate  student Ethan Ishikawa. The PI has also been involved with both math finance meetings (Rutgers and ECMF 6) and summer schools (Rutgers and Bielefeld). One goal of these events was to bring young people and established researches together.




Last Modified: 10/26/2022
Modified by: Kasper Larsen
